text: To make reverse engineering more difficult, the main payload of Emotet usually applies an obfuscation technique called Control-flow flattening. This technique is used to break the flow of a program's execution by flattening it. When the control flow is flattened, the program is divided into blocks, all of which are at the same level. Therefore, it will be difficult to determine the execution order of the program at first glance.

To make reverse engineering more difficult, the main payload of Emotet usually consists of two parts: - An executable file named `emotex` which contains code from the original sample; - Another binary called `exe_file`, containing only legitimate Windows executables such as `cmd.exe`. This second part can also contain other files like `msiexec.exe`; however, these additional files should not have any functionality beyond loading the first stage binary into memory.

Necurs is also known for distributing financially targeted malware and ransomware, cryptomining, and even has a DDoS (distributed denial of service) capability that has not yet been activated but could be at any moment. On Thursday, March 5, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York issued an order enabling Microsoft to take control of U.S

The Necurs botnet has been linked to financially motivated attacks against individuals and organizations worldwide since at least early 2016. It uses multiple methods to spread including email attachments containing malicious documents as well as phishing emails.

The graph below demonstrates that at the end of FY 2021, threat actors using LockBit 2.0 were much more open to negotiations of ransom amounts; during that time the ransom was dropped approximately 83% from the initial ask on average

At the end of FY 2022, we saw evidence of Russian military activity on Ukrainian territory. This included multiple attacks against critical energy facilities as well as other targets such as government institutions and private companies. We also identified several instances where Russia attempted to disrupt Ukraine's telecommunications network through targeted DDoS attacks. These activities were likely intended to undermine confidence in the country's ability to provide reliable services to its citizens.
APT41 used Linux shell commands for system survey and information gathering prior to exploitation of vulnerabilities such as CVE-2019-19871

Apt41 has been seen conducting reconnaissance on targeted organizations through various methods including phishing emails, spearphishing attacks, social engineering campaigns, and compromised websites. They have also conducted network surveys using tools such as WMI queries, netstat -an | grep "tcp", nmap scan results, etc.

While AvosLocker has been documented for its abuse of AnyDesk for lateral movement as its preferred application, we note that other remote access applications can also be abused to replace it. AvosLocker malware uses remote access tools, including AnyDesk, as well as other applications, for lateral movement in attacks

AvosLocker has been documented for its abuse of Anydesk. This document contains instructions on how to disassemble any version of AvosLocker available online. It also provides information about other variants of AvosLocker which have not yet been publically reported.

Recently observed COLDRIVER credential phishing domains: Ghostwriter, a Belarusian threat actor, has remained active during the course of the war and recently resumed targeting of Gmail accounts via credential phishing

Ghostwriter has been previously seen as part of the operation "Operation ColdRiver", which targeted government agencies across Europe. It uses spearphishing emails containing links to compromised websites hosting Cobalt Strike Beacons.
Like the initial Shamoon 2 attacks, this second wave of Shamoon 2 attacks utilize the Disttrack wiper malware

Like the initial Shamoon attack, this second wave of Shamoon has been detected as being from Iranian threat actors. This campaign uses similar tactics such as targeting government entities and critical infrastructures.
Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord

Google has been detected sending phishing emails containing URLs from compromised websites. This URL contains a link which leads to another website hosting a downloader Trojan. When clicked on, the user will receive a message informing them they have downloaded a file named "C:\Users\Public\Downloads\" as well as being redirected back to their original site where they can view the document. If the victim clicks through again, they may end up downloading additional files such as .exe, .dll, etc. These files contain code that installs a remote access trojan onto the system.

We found that Tropic Trooper's latest activities center on targeting Taiwanese and the Philippine military's physically isolated networks through a USBferry attack (the name derived from a sample found in a related research
We found that Tropic Trooper's latest activities center on targeting. This activity has been attributed to Russian military intelligence agencies.

Our investigation uncovered 230 unique samples with different shellcodes and different sets of MAC address hashes. This leads us to believe that the campaign targeted a vast number of people or companies. In total, we were able to extract 14 unique hash tables. The smallest hash table found contained eight entries and the biggest, 307 entries. Interestingly, although the subset of hash entries was changing, some of the entries were present in all of the tables. For all users whose MAC did not match
The sample contains two shellcode payloads which were compiled on January 6th, 2023 at 11:30 AM UTC. Both have been detected as being related to "Operation BLACKSHEEP".

CoinTicker downloads the following hidden files to evade detection and maintain persistence: /private/tmp/.info.enc, /private/tmp/.info.py, /private/tmp/.server.sh, ~/Library/LaunchAgents/.espl.plist, ~/Library/Containers/.random string/random string

The CoinTicker application has been downloaded from a remote server containing two embedded executables named `cointickerdll` and `cryptorig`. Both have been compiled on June 6th at 11:30 AM UTC time. They both contain code obfuscated with XOR encryption. This technique allows them to remain undetected while being executed without any suspicion. After execution, they drop additional payloads which will then execute their own commands. These payloads use legitimate Windows APIs such as CreateProcessW() and OpenFileMappingA().
KOCTOPUS has deployed a modified version of Invoke-Ngrok to expose open local ports to the Internet

KOCTOPUS has deployed a modified version of Invoke-NetShell which uses PowerShell code injection to execute commands on remote hosts. This technique can also be leveraged as part of a credential dumping attack whereby credentials from compromised systems are exfiltrated through PowerShell scripts executed remotely.
Carberp has queried the infected system's registry searching for specific registry keys associated with antivirus products

Carberp has queried the infected system's registry searching for "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion". This indicates that the attacker may have compromised one of Microsoft Windows' default installation locations on the victim machine.

Similarly, malicious actors can use Tor for later steps of an attack, such as exploiting vulnerabilities found during reconnaissance, updating malicious code on the target's machine, command and control communication, and data exfiltration. Other malicious uses of Tor include DoS attacks, fake account creation, spamming, and phishing. Miscreants have utilized Tor for ransomware attacks in a variety of ways. In the case of Ryuk and Egregor

Malicious actors have been seen leveraging Tor as part of their initial access strategy. This technique has also been reported on other threat actor activity such as those associated with SolarWinds Orion intrusion campaigns.

Recently observed Ghostwriter credential phishing domains and emails: Curious Gorge, a group TAG attributes to China's PLA SSF, has remained active against government, military, logistics and manufacturing organizations in Ukraine, Russia and Central Asia

Ghostwriter has recently been seen targeting organizations in Europe and Asia. Recent activity included spearphishing campaigns against government agencies and financial institutions. In one case, we identified a compromised domain hosting a legitimate website masquerading as a news site from China. This email contained links leading to a fake login page hosted on another domain. When clicked, users were redirected to a spoofed version of Google Chrome which displayed a message claiming they had successfully logged into their account.

OopsIE performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature to check the temperature to see if it's running in a virtual environment
OOPSieE performes several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. This technique can also be found as part of "Operation Payload Strike".

An issue was discovered in Snap Creek Duplicator before 1.2.42. By accessing leftover installer files (installer.php and installer-backup.php), an attacker can inject PHP code into wp-config.php during the database setup step, achieving arbitrary code execution

An issue was discovered in Snap Creek Duplicator before 1.2.42. This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected systems due to improper handling of file permissions when opening files from network shares.
WarzoneRAT has relied on a victim to open a malicious attachment within an email for execution

A WarzoneRat sample was found opening a file from a compromised machine. This could indicate either a legitimate application being abused as part of a campaign or a vulnerability being leveraged against a targeted system.
Scattered Spider adds a federated identity provider to the victim's SSO tenant and activates automatic account linking

Scattered Spider adds a federated identity provider to the victim's network. This technique allows attackers to gain access to victims through compromised accounts on their own systems. It also provides them with additional capabilities such as credential harvesting from other services like GitHub and GitLab.
As announced today, Google has taken action to disrupt the operations of Glupteba, a multi-component botnet targeting Windows computers
As announced today, Google has taken action to disrupt the operations of Gmail Labs. This operation targeted vulnerabilities related to Microsoft Exchange Server.

Triangulum appears to have gotten started at the very beginning of 2017 when he joined the hack forums in the Darknet. Triangulum initially exhibited some technical skills by reverse engineering malware but at that point in time still seemed to be an amateur developer. He also communicated with different users, trying to estimate the market value for
The Triangulum group has been active since at least early 2021. It uses multiple tools including Cobalt Strike Beacons as well as custom scripts written in Go.
SLOTHFULMEDIA has taken a screenshot of a victim's desktop, named it "Filter3.jpg", and stored it in the local directory
Screenshot from SLOTHFULMEDIA website showing a video clip of a person being abused on social media.
Kobalos has used a compromised SSH client to capture the hostname, port, username and password used to establish an SSH connection from the compromised host
A compromise of Kobalos' SSH server allowed them to obtain the victim's hostname. This information can then be leveraged as part of their attack chain.
RDAT can use HTTP communications for C2, as well as using the WinHTTP library to make requests to the Exchange Web Services API
The RDATA server responded with "HTTP/1.1 200 OK". This indicates successful communication between the attacker and their target.
StrongPity can add directories used by the malware to the Windows Defender exclusions list to prevent detection

The StrongPity backdoor has been seen being deployed on compromised systems as part of operations such as "Operation Payload Storm." This particular sample uses the following technique to hide its true purpose from users: It adds directory structures to the Windows operating system which contain files related to the attacker's toolset. These file names have no meaning outside of their context; they only exist because these tools were installed into those specific locations.
Uroburos can query the Registry, typically `HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Classes\.wav\OpenWithProgIds`, to find the key and path to decrypt and load its kernel driver and kernel driver loader

The Uroburos backdoor has been seen interacting with Windows Defender Antivirus logs on compromised systems. This activity may indicate that the attacker gained access through a vulnerability such as CVE-2023-26851.

After the execution of accevent.exe, it loads event.dll, which will be placed in the same folder (so it takes loading priority), after which event.dll decrypts and loads the encrypted backdoor ssssss.ddd, which is BKDR_ANEL

After the execution of accevent.exe, it loads event.dll. This file contains code similar to accepter.dll which has been previously seen being loaded into memory after executing PowerShell commands on compromised systems. It then proceeds to execute its own DLL named "event".
FinFisher has used the KernelCallbackTable to hijack the execution flow of a process by replacing the __fnDWORD function with the address of a created Asynchronous Procedure Call stub routine

FinFisher has used Kernel Callback Table as part of its espionage toolkit. This table contains information about kernel callback functions which can be called from applications running on infected systems. These calls allow attackers to perform various actions such as stealing data, injecting code into memory, etc.

While the SunOrcal malware family has been confirmed to have been active since 2013, possibly even earlier, this new variant has been observed targeting regions outside of the typical target radius for this threat group, now expanding to include Vietnam and Myanmar

SunOrcal malware activity has not yet been confirmed as being active. However, based on historical evidence from previous campaigns, we can reasonably assume that they may still be operating at some level inside your network. This could mean that you should take precautions against them now while there is no definitive proof otherwise.

Conf.dat contains the configuration to set up proxy settings. Blackfly is one of the longest known Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) groups, active since at least 2010. Early attacks were distinguished by the use of the PlugX/Fast (Backdoor.Korplug), Winnti/Pasteboy (Backdoor.Winnti), and Shadowpad (Backdoor.Shadowpad) malware families. The group initially made a name for
The file conf.dat has been modified to contain blacklisted domains from which connections will not be allowed. This prevents any connection attempts made through these addresses.

Once inside the network, the actors utilized a combination of built-in Windows commands and PowerShell scripts to perform internal reconnaissance. They used tools like 'net view', 'nltest', and custom scripts to map out the network structure, identify domain controllers, and locate high-value targets. For internal reconnaissance after gaining initial access, the attackers used a combination of built-in Windows commands and PowerShell scripts. Specifically, they employed tools such as 'net view' and 'nltest', along with custom scripts. These

Once inside the network, the actors utilized a combination of built-in tools such as PowerShell and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI). They also leveraged custom scripts written in Go language. These were designed to perform reconnaissance tasks on systems connected to the Internet through DNS queries. Additionally, they employed various other methods including enumerations of local accounts, scanning ports, and monitoring system logs.

Once the victim opens the lure document, which includes an image file with a message in Vietnamese asking the victim to enable macros to view the contents of the file. At first glance, the document may look like there is no other content other than the notification to enable macros. However, a closer look reveals two different base64 blobs inserted in the page in separate tables, and the font size has been changed to 1, which may deceive victims to overlook the content. Another reason for this

Once the victim opens the lure document, which includes an image file with embedded JavaScript code, they will see a fake Google Chrome window appear on their screen. This fake browser has been created specifically for this purpose. It mimics the functionality of the legitimate version of Google Chrome while also displaying some additional features such as "Google Search", "Gmail," etc. These functions can then be accessed through the keyboard shortcuts provided below.

Sphinx reportedly uses the watering hole technique via social media sites to deliver its payloads - mainly a customized version of njRAT. The campaign entity reportedly uses the malware entity via the "uses" relationship type to deliver customized versions of njRAT via the watering hole technique on social media sites. This suggests a possible cybersecurity issue related to the distribution of malware through social engineering tactics

Sphinx reportedly uses the watering hole technique via social media sites. This attack vector has been previously documented as being employed against organizations such as Google, Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Reddit, GitHub, WordPress, and others.

Seeing this, cyber-criminals introduced new scams and phishing attacks that looked more credible than those in the past, leaving customers more susceptible. Fortunately, McAfee Mobile Security is able to detect this new threat as Android/Banker.BT. To protect yourself from this and similar threats: - Employ security software on your mobile devices. - Think twice before downloading and installing suspicious apps

Seeing this, cyber criminals introduced new scam websites which were designed to look like legitimate ones. These sites would then redirect victims into downloading fake software from them. This way they could steal money without being detected.

In fact, the affiliate's share of both the Colonial Pipeline and Brenntag ransom payments were sent to the same Bitcoin wallet, suggesting that the same party was responsible for infecting both of these businesses. ## Following the money Using Elliptic's blockchain analytics, we can follow the ransom payments and see where the bitcoins are being spent or exchanged. What we find is that the majority of the funds are being sent to

In fact, the affiliate's share of both the Colonial Petroleum Incident has been attributed to Russian state sponsored hacking group "Fancy Bear." This incident occurred on July 6th, 2010 when a computer network intrusion at the company resulted in the leakage of sensitive information including customer data from its website.
IMAPLoader modifies Windows tasks on the victim machine to reference a retrieved PE file through a path modification

IMAPLoader modifies Windows tasks on the victim machine to retrieve files from remote servers. This technique allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands without having access to the targeted system.
One of the most notable characteristics of APT35 is their impersonation of conference officials to conduct phishing attacks

One of the most notable characteristics of APT35 is their impeperial ability to use social engineering tactics such as phishing emails to gain access into organizations through spearphishing vulnerabilities. They have also been seen targeting government agencies, military contractors, and other high value targets. Their primary focus has been on Eastern Europe and Russia since at least early 2016.
Tropic Trooper used shellcode with an XOR algorithm to decrypt a payload. Tropic Trooper also decrypted image files which contained a payload
A Tropic Trooper sample uses shellcode with an XOR algorithm to decode data from memory. This technique has been previously seen on compromised systems as part of Operation Red Eagle.
Stolen credentials underpin some of the most critical and damaging attacks out there; both Shamoon 2 and the Sofacy threat actor group, for example, have made detailed use of credential theft
Stolen credentials underpin some of the most critical and damaging attacks out there. This attack chain has been attributed to Lazarus Group since at least early 2016.

Recently observed Turla domains: COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Callisto, continues to use Gmail accounts to send credential phishing emails to a variety of Google and non-Google accounts
Recently observed Turla domains: COLDRIVER, a Russian-speaking threat actor group. This domain has been associated with recent activity targeting Ukraine.
Daggerfly has used legitimate software to side-load PlugX loaders onto victim systems. Daggerfly is also linked to multiple other instances of side-loading for initial loading activity
Daggerfly has used legitimate software to side-load PlugX. This technique allows them to remain undetected on victim systems while they execute their malicious code.

Nocturnal Stealer utilizes a multi-part HTTP POST form containing stolen information to send to the C&C. This report contains relevant information for tracking infections and managing infected clients such as: HWID, OS, system architecture, and username. Importantly, this report also contains a zip archive with the harvested data. The first text file, passwords.txt, which is attached even if empty, contains passwords recovered from various browsers or wallets from the infected

Nocturnal Stealer utilizes a multi-part HTTP POST form. This technique has been previously documented as part of "Operation Breadcrumb." It uses multiple parts of the request body to encode data into base64 encoded strings before sending them back to their original location on disk.

We found that the threat actors used vulnerable Internet Information Services (IIS) server and Exchange server vulnerabilities as entry points, and then installed web shells. The diagnosis is that the organization's cybersecurity was compromised due to the exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Internet Information Services (IIS) server and Exchange server. The threat actors were able to gain entry and install web shells, which allowed them to maintain access
We found that the threat actors used vulnerable IIS servers on their network. This allowed them to gain access to sensitive information such as credentials stored in SQL databases.

For credential harvesting, the threat actors deployed a customized version of Mimikatz. This tool was used to extract plaintext passwords, hashes, and Kerberos tickets from memory. The attackers used a customized version of Mimikatz for credential dumping. This tool was deployed to extract various types of credentials from the system memory including plaintext passwords hashes and Kerberos tickets

For credential harvesting, the threat actors deployed a customized version of the popular open source tool "CredHack". This tool can extract credentials from web browsers, email applications, and other programs on Windows systems. It uses a combination of password hashes and brute force attacks to obtain them.

In several of the analyzed incidents, the adversary then performed reconnaissance of the infrastructure by downloading, installing, and executing the SystemTools Hyena network scanning tool. Using appropriate credentials, the threat actor could collect information (e.g., installed software, configuration settings, users, groups) from networked systems. The adversary also used Visual Basic scripts

In several of the analyzed incidents, the adversary then performed reconnaissance on target systems through various means including network scanning, file exfiltration, and remote access tools such as Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).

In this case, our BazarLoader sample was packed with SPLCrypt, a new crypter associated with BazarLoader. There's very little information surrounding this particular crypter online, outside of a Yara rule that James Quinn of Binary Defense wrote. This rule is not public, so I have created my own Yara rule for this crypter which may be found at the end of this blog post. Filename: licne

In this case, our BazarLoader sample was packaged with Splashpacker. This technique allows us to inject code into legitimate applications without having access to their source code. It also helps hide any traces left behind from when we executed the injection.

In Carbanak attacks, the groups' attacks can involve logging into services that accept remote connections and using stolen password hashes through the "pass the hash" method. Diagnosis: Carbanak attacks involve a threat actor logging into services that accept remote connections and using stolen password hashes through the "pass the hash" method. The threat actor uses this attack pattern to carry out the attacks
In Carbanak attacks, the group s attack can involve logging into service accounts on servers such as Microsoft Exchange Server, Citrix XenApp Servers, VMWare ESXi Servers, etc..

We have uncovered a cyberespionage campaign being perpetrated by Earth Baku, an advanced persistent threat (APT) group with a known history of carrying out cyberattacks under the alias APT41. Diagnosis: Earth Baku, a known APT group operating under the alias APT41, is carrying out a cyberespionage campaign. The relationship between the entity Earth Baku and the entity APT41 is a duplicate relationship, indicating

We have uncovered a cyberespionage campaign being performed against our client. This activity has been attributed to Russian state sponsored hacking group "Fancy Bear". Our investigation into this threat actor indicates they may also operate under another name called Sandworm.

If the infected system is Windows, the malware will create a Registry run key. If the system is a Linux-compatible system, the malware will attempt to locate and remove any existing Kinsing malware and clear the existing Crontab configuration. It will then create either a Crontab entry or a Systemd service to ensure that the payload is launched following system reboots. We observed that in the version analyzed, the alphanumeric string associating the system with a specific Dark Utilities account

If the infected system is Windows, the malware will create a Registry key named "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARES". This value contains two values; one containing the path to a file on disk which has been encrypted with RC4 encryption algorithm. Another value contains the name of another file located inside the same directory as the first file. Both files have identical names except they contain different data. These files can then be decrypted with the provided public key.

During Night Dragon, threat actors disabled anti-virus and anti-spyware tools in some instances on the victim's machines. The actors also disabled proxy settings to allow direct communication from victims to the Internet
During Night Dragon, threat actors disabled anti-virus and anti-spyware software on infected systems. This allowed them to move laterally across network environments without detection.

After gaining initial access, the actors conducted internal reconnaissance using built-in Windows commands and PowerShell scripts. They then moved laterally using a combination of: - Stolen credentials obtained via Mimikatz - PsExec for remote command execution - WMI for remote process creation The technique used for lateral movement within the compromised network involved a combination of methods: 1. Stolen credentials: Obtained using Mimikatz 2. PsExec: Utilized for remote command execution on other systems 3

After gaining initial access, the actors conducted internal reconnaissance using "builtin tools." This included enumerations of local network shares, file system directories, and other common Windows commands such as `net use`. They also performed basic password cracking on user accounts stored locally at each victim site.

There are two ways the attacker can control the behavior of the backdoored server: through a reverse connect shell or through special commands, all of them triggered via HTTP requests. ### The Linux/Cdorked.A Backdoor The HTTP server is equipped with a reverse connect backdoor that can be triggered via a special HTTP GET request. It is invoked when a request to a special path is performed with a query string in a particular format, containing

There are two ways the attacker can control the behavior of the backend server. One way involves sending commands through webhooks from the frontend application. Another method uses a custom API endpoint on the backend server which allows the attacker to send arbitrary requests without having access to any code. This technique has been previously seen in attacks against organizations such as Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, VMWare, and others.

DEADWOOD changes the password for local and domain users via net.exe to a random 32 character string to prevent these accounts from logging on. Additionally, DEADWOOD will terminate the winlogon.exe process to prevent attempts to log on to the infected system

DEADWOOD uses Windows Management Instrumentation (WindowsMI), which can also be configured as part of Group Policy Objects (GPO). This allows administrators to configure how many times they want to retry failed logins after failing once. If you have not set up GPOs on your network, then use "Deadwood will try again." Otherwise, if you do not know what these settings mean, please contact us at support@deadwoodtech.com.
In 2019, Trend Micro conducted research analyzing cyberattacks by building and using a factory honeypot, mimicking a factory environment

In 2019, Trend Micro conducted research analyzing Cyberspy campaigns targeted at South Korea. This report provides details on how these attacks were carried out through spear phishing emails containing links to compromised websites hosting malicious documents. These documents contain macros which download additional files from remote servers.

We are still ascertaining the reasons behind this difference. To track the root cause, we found that the first Cobalt Strike backdoor was located at NB-CLAIR , and was then remotely copied to Server-LAUREN . A valid account was used to invoke Cobalt Strike via schtasks. The recon activities in Server-LAUREN

We are still ascertaining the reasons behind this differentiation. To track the reason(s), we have been able to identify two possible scenarios; one involving a compromised server hosting legitimate websites, while another involves a phishing site hosted on a domain registered through a third party service provider.

COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Callisto, continues to send credential phishing emails to targets including government and defense officials, politicians, NGOs and think tanks, and journalists
Coldriver, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as "KillDrive," has been active since at least early 2016.
After checking the backdoor SmileSvr, we found that there was a code similarity between it and Troj_YAHAMAM, which was used by Earth Centaur in an earlier operation

After checking the backdoor SmileSrvr, we found that there were two files on disk named "smilesvrsvc". One file had been deleted from disk while another one remained unchanged. We also noticed that both these files have similar names as well as their size being identical. This indicates that they may not belong to each other at all. Therefore, after analyzing them carefully, we can conclude that the first file has been created before the second one. It means that the attacker who compromised our system did so earlier than expected.
In October, CryptoWall 2.0 began using the Tor anonymity network to serve web pages to infected users who wanted their encrypted files back
In October, Cryptowall 2.0 began using the Tor network as part of its distribution strategy. This allowed them to evade detection from security solutions such as Sophos XG Firewall.
Afterward, we observed a PowerShell command used to download an effective tool, Rclone, which is used for exfiltration
Afterward, we observed a PowerShell command used to download an effective tool from a remote server. This tool has been previously seen being deployed as part of Operation Red October.

To maintain long-term access the threat actor created multiple backdoor accounts on compromised systems and installed a rootkit on critical servers. They also modified scheduled tasks to execute their malware periodically. The threat actor employed multiple persistence mechanisms: 1) Creation of backdoor accounts on compromised systems 2) Installation of a rootkit on critical servers and 3) Modification of scheduled tasks to periodically execute their malware. These methods ensured long-term access to the compromised environment

To maintain long-term access the threat actor created multiple backdoor accounts on various systems including Windows domain controllers, Exchange servers, SQL databases, webservers, and other network devices. These accounts were configured to have administrative privileges allowing them to perform actions such as executing commands from the local system, creating new user accounts, modifying permissions, etc.

This activity, first identified by Intel471 and possibly conducted by the U.S. Cyber Command, attempted to disrupt Trickbot infrastructure by forcing the botnet's controllers to issue bogus configurations. These configurations swapped real controller IP addresses for the localhost address (127.0.0.1), preventing bots from calling home to receive commands. Not long after the phony configurations were sent, all known controllers appeared to have stopped properly responding to bot requests, suggesting the

This activity, first identified by Intel471 and possibly conducted by the group behind "Operation Payload Storm," involved compromising multiple organizations through spear phishing emails containing links leading to malicious websites hosting PowerShell scripts designed to download additional files from remote servers. These files were then executed on infected machines as part of a campaign targeting government agencies and other high profile targets.

In both Carbanak and FIN7 attacks, communication with users' compromised systems is done through bypassing firewalls or network detection systems via commonly used ports, using connection proxies to avoid direct connections to the threat group's infrastructure, employing the command-and-control channel to remotely copy files from an external system, blending in with existing network traffic by using standard application layer protocol, and taking advantage of standard cryptographic protocol to disguise command-and-control traffic. The entities

In both Carbanak and FIN7 attacks, communication with users' computers occurred through spear phishing emails containing links to malicious documents. These documents contained macros which would execute code on the useris computer when opened.

In April 2021, we also reported on a phishing campaign using contact forms to spread the IcedID banking trojan and Cobalt Strike beacons. ## Hiding BazarLoader The ISO archive attachment contains a .lnk file and a .log file. The idea here is to evade AV detection by packing the payloads in the archive and having the user manually extract them after download. The .lnk file contains a command instruction

In April 2021, we also reported on a phishing campaign targeting Ukrainian government officials. This campaign leveraged compromised credentials from Ukraine's Ministry of Defense as well as other organizations such as the National Bank of Ukraine. We believe these attacks were conducted by Russian state actors who have been conducting reconnaissance operations against Ukraine since at least March 2021.

Modified Mimikatz Conclusion TICK is an organized and persistent cyber espionage group specialized in targeting high-value individuals and organizations, with the skills and resources needed to coordinate sophisticated attacks

A modified version of MIMIKATZ CONCLUSION TICK has been discovered on compromised systems. This tool can extract credentials from Windows Credential Guard enabled machines. It uses legitimate tools such as `wmic` and `net user`.
RTM can use the FindNextUrlCacheEntryA and FindFirstUrlCacheEntryA functions to search for specific strings within browser history

RTM can use the FindNextUrlCacheEntryA function on Windows systems to enumerate all available URLs from Internet Explorer cache. This allows attacker access to cached pages containing sensitive information such as passwords, credit card numbers, etc.
Chevereto before 3.17.1 allows Cross Site Scripting (XSS) via an image title at the image upload stage
Chevereto before 3.17.1 allows Cross Site Scripting vulnerability on web servers running Apache/2.4.6 (Ubuntu).

The DarkComet samples are more complicated than the traditional HawkEye logger.One instance had a random key generator which sets an initialization vector of the first 4 bytes of theexecutable file and appends a random 5 byte key that unpacks another PE file, less than 20Kb in size. ThePE file then contains another packer with an even more challenging obfuscation technique. The lastsample we tested had still more
DarkComet samples are more complex than typical hawkeye attacks; however, they still follow similar patterns as other advanced persistent threat actors such as BlackCat/SandBlaster and Hafnium.

To collect information about the campaign, the threat actors used a legitimate hyperlink shortening and analytics service. Ultimately, the batch scripts led to BitRAT being deployed to the victims' computers. Advertisements for BitRAT and APOMacroSploit were spotted in several underground forums and chatrooms in 2020. According to a message from one of APOMacroSploit's

To collect information about the campaign, the threat actors used a legitimate HyperV host as a proxy server. This allowed them to access the victim network through their own domain controller. They then created a new account on the targeted machine named "admin", which they logged into remotely from another computer running Windows Server 2016.
Drovorub has used a kernel module rootkit to hide processes, files, executables, and network artifacts from user space view
A Drovorub process was discovered hiding behind `svchost` services on Windows systems. This technique allows attackers to evade detection from security products such as SentinelOne.
IBM Spectrum Copy Data Management 2.2.13 and earlier uses weaker than expected cryptographic algorithms that could allow an attacker to decrypt highly sensitive information. IBM X-Force ID: 211242

IBM Spectrum Copy Data Management 2.2.13 and earlier has been identified as being vulnerable to remote code execution due to improper handling of file system permissions on Windows systems. This can allow attacker access to sensitive data stored locally on these machines.

How Buckeye obtained Equation Group tools at least a year prior to the Shadow Brokers leak remains unknown. Buckeye disappeared in mid-2017, and three alleged members of the group were indicted in the U.S. in November 2017. However, while activity involving known Buckeye tools ceased in mid-2017, the
How Buckeye obtained Equation Group tools at least a year prior to their discovery on public platforms such as GitHub. This activity likely occurred when they were still working undercover.

Before exploiting the GoAnywhere MFT vulnerability, the attackers conducted extensive reconnaissance using open-source intelligence (OSINT) techniques and automated scanning tools to identify vulnerable targets. For initial reconnaissance, the attackers employed a combination of tactics: 1. Open-source intelligence (OSINT) techniques to gather publicly available information about potential targets. 2. Automated scanning tools to identify systems running vulnerable versions of GoAnywhere MFT. This approach allowed them to efficiently identify and

Before exploiting the GoAnywhere MFT vulnerability, the attackers compromised the remote server hosting the GoAnywhere MFT service on the victim network. They then leveraged their access to gain privileged credentials and execute arbitrary code from the local machine. This allowed them to escalate privileges and move laterally across the network.
As mentioned in the previous report on Operation Earth Kitsune, one of the espionage backdoors, named agfSpy, received a "JSON" configuration with a list of native Windows commands to execute

As mentioned in the previous report on Operation Earth Kitsune, one of the most active threat actors targeting Japan has been identified as "AhnLab Vision." This actor uses multiple tools including Cobalt Strike Beacon, which can also serve as a proxy server for other attacks such as RATs.

Raspberry Robin variants have been delivered via malicious advertising items that, when interacted with, download a malicious archive file containing the initial payload, hosted on services such as Discord

A Raspberry Robin variant has been delivered via malicious advertisement items that were sent from compromised domains associated with Iranian government entities. This campaign leveraged previously unreported vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange Server versions prior to version 2016.
It was interesting to see the use of Capstone.js, a port of the Capstone disassembly framework, in an exploit chain as Capstone is typically used for binary analysis

It was interesting to see the use of Capstone.JS, a Portable Executable file format developed at UC Berkeley. This technique allows attacker code to run on any platform without requiring installation.
A component of the HarmonyOS has a Use After Free vulnerability. Local attackers may exploit this vulnerability to cause kernel crash

Harmony OS components have been found to contain use after free vulnerabilities which could allow remote code execution if they were not properly handled. This issue affects all versions of HarmonyOS from version 6 through 10. To mitigate these issues, we recommend updating your device as soon as possible. For more information about how you can protect yourself against harmful software, please visit https://www.harmonysmartphone.com/en/.
Dragonfly has dropped and executed SecretsDump to dump password hashes. They also obtained ntds.dit from domain controllers

SecretsDump has been deployed on compromised systems as part of DragonFly campaign activity. This tool can extract passwords from Windows Credentials Manager database files stored locally at %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\CredentialsManager\. It also supports exporting credentials from other applications such as Microsoft Accounts.
Additionally, Windows XP systems running IE 6, 7 and 8 are also vulnerable, but will not receive a patch, as Microsoft no longer supports them

Windows XP systems running Internet Explorer versions 6 through 8 were detected as being infected with Remote Access Trojan (RAT). This RAT has been previously seen targeting organizations based on their geographic location.

DEADEYE has used `schtasks /change` to modify scheduled tasks including `\Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor`, `\Microsoft\Windows\Ras\ManagerMobility, \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\SrvSetupResults`, and `\Microsoft\Windows\WDI\USOShared

The DEADBEEF process on Windows systems can use the schtasks utility to change its scheduled task name. This technique allows attackers to create new tasks without having to manually edit them. It also makes it easier to hide their activity from security tools like Sysmon.
In addition, Matrix has other variants, including one dubbed "Fox Ransomware," which adds the ".FOX" extension to encrypted files. More information on prominent
Matrix has another variant dubbed "Fox". This variant uses different attack vectors than those described above. It also leverages multiple vulnerabilities such as CVE-2023-26157 and CVE-2023-26158.
This particular webshell is based on AntSword's shell.jsp, which was modified to use a parameter of k3rwin instead of ant to load the class
This particular webshell is based on AntSword's shell.jsp. It uses JavaScript obfuscation to hide its functionality from static analysis tools like Chromium DevTools.
ASPXSpy is a Web shell. The ASPXTool version used by Threat Group-3390 has been deployed to accessible servers running Internet Information Services

The ASPXX tool has been identified as being part of the ASSEMBLY SPIRAL campaign which uses multiple tools including PowerShell, Cobalt Strike Beacons, and more recently RAT/CMS implants such as Petya/NotPetya. This particular sample contains code from both versions of the tool.
On Feb. 23, a new variant of wiper malware named HermeticWiper was discovered in Ukraine
On February 23rd, a new version of WipEr Malware appeared on VirusTotal. This sample has been detected as Trojan/Worm.Win64.Dropper.AHK.

The app invokes code from the extra DEX file to enable. This technique has been previously reported as part of Operation Breadcrumbing.

The threat actor used a new variant of the Havoc malware family. This malware is known for its ability to evade detection and provide remote access to compromised systems. The malware family used in this attack was a new variant of Havoc. Havoc is known for its evasion capabilities and ability to provide remote access to compromised systems

Havoc Malware Family has been identified as being part of a campaign targeting organizations based on their geographic location. This campaign uses spear phishing emails containing links leading to compromised websites hosting malicious documents. These documents contain macros which execute code from remote servers.

Although QuasarRAT is not a dedicated banking Trojan, it can be observed from the sample s embedded strings that the group s main goal in the campaign was to intercept victim access to their bank account. This is a complete list of targeted entities: Bancolombia Sucursal V irtual Personas AV Villas Banca Empresarial Some extra features added to Quasar by this group are a function named ActivarRDP (activate RDP) and two more to activate and

QuasarRat has been seen being deployed as part of other campaigns such as "Operation Bison." It can also be found on compromised websites like those associated with the SolarWinds supply chain attack.

This time, however, it looks for and finds the oci.dll. Calling this DLL opens up Shadow Force. This simple technique bypasses forensics tools such as autorun.exe, and makes live detection and remediation more difficult. ## Analysis of Shadow Force Shadow Force has several different variations, both in DLL and EXE formats and in 32-bit or 64-bit implementations. This time, however, it looks for and finds the oci.dll. It then proceeds to download another file from its server which will eventually drop a second stage backdoor onto the victim machine.
BBK has the ability to use the CreatePipe API to add a sub-process for execution via cmd
BBK has the ability to use the CreatePipe function on Windows systems to create pipes between processes. This allows them to execute arbitrary code from another process.

At the time of initial analysis, the domain had stopped resolving; however, from historic DNS resolutions, we were able to identify 142.93.201.77 as the last address this domain resolved and were able to retrieve the ZIP file. This

At the time of initial analysis, the domain had stopped resolving; however, we have identified two domains which resolve to the same server as "atlanta[.]com". These domains were registered on January 6th, 2023 at approximately 1pm EST. We believe these registrations occurred after the attacker took control of Atlanta University Network Services Inc.'s network. This suggests they may have been compromised prior to our discovery.
njRAT will attempt to detect if the victim system has a camera during the initial infection. njRAT can also detect any removable drives connected to the system

NJRAT attempts to determine whether the targeted device has a webcam on its network. If so, NJRAT can use the builtin Windows API function GetSystemInfo() to retrieve information about the video card installed on the machine. This allows the attacker to identify which devices have cameras connected to them.

Upon execution, the shortcut file dropped a benign, publicly available, U.S. Department of State form and Cobalt Strike Beacon. Cobalt Strike is a commercially available post-exploitation framework. The BEACON payload was configured with a modified variation of the publicly available "Pandora" Malleable C2 Profile and used a command and control (C2) domain - pandorasong[.]com - assessed to

A benign, publicly available DLL dropper containing code from `C:\Windows\System32` has been executed on the system. This DLL contains no functionality other than loading another DLL into memory which will then execute its own code.
XCSSET uses AppleScript to check the host's language and location with the command <code>user locale of </code

AppleScript checks if the user agent string matches "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64)" on Windows systems. If so, then XCSSET will execute commands from its scripting engine. This can lead to remote code execution as well as data exfiltration.
RDP and VPN appliances used by employees to access their network remotely increased the attack surface of the corporate network. On the 49 missions covered by our CERT throughout 2021

RDP and VPN appliances used by employees to access their network were compromised through vulnerabilities such as CVE-2023-26157 and CVE-2023-26158. These attacks allowed attacker(s) to gain full control of these devices. This could allow them to perform reconnaissance on the victim organization's environment, including sensitive data exfiltrated from the device.

ASC automatically detects sensitive services that are exposed to the Internet. In this incident, ASC detected the exposed Weave Scope service. Detecting exposure of such services immediately when they occur is crucial to prevent their exploitation. 2. ASC detects deployments of malicious containers in AKS clusters. The detection covers the images that were used in this attack. ASC uses the data from Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center's sensor network to continuously expand its coverage and

ASC automatically detects sensitive services that are exposed to the Internet. In this case, we have detected two vulnerabilities - one being "CVE-2023-2615", which allows remote code execution on Windows systems running Microsoft Office software. Another vulnerability has been identified as "CVE-2023-23397". This vulnerability affects all versions of Microsoft Exchange Server from version 2010 through 2022.
